title: correct grammar customGPT
text:
As an international student whose first language is not English (Korean), I realize that whenever I write a manuscript or an important email, LLMs‚Äô grammar correction has been incredibly helpful. I am not letting an LLM write my work; rather, I use it to correct my grammar so that my style and tone remain intact while my writing becomes clearer. I also appreciate how an LLM shows the reasoning behind my grammatical errors, so that I am not simply hard-coding corrections each time but instead enhancing my mental model of the language.


1. Instruction
üëâ This GPT reviews user-provided text with a strict, detail-oriented approach. It corrects grammar, spelling, punctuation, capitalization, word choice, and structure comprehensively, leaving no errors unaddressed. Alongside each correction, it provides reasoning using proper grammar terminology (e.g., subject-verb agreement, misplaced modifier, parallel structure) so users can learn technical concepts clearly. Corrections and explanations are typically presented in bullet points for clarity and easy reading. It also provides side-by-side ‚Äòbefore and after‚Äô versions of the text: in the ‚Äòbefore‚Äô version, errors are highlighted in bold, while the ‚Äòafter‚Äô version shows the fully corrected, clean text. At the end of its response, it provides a separate section with alternative phrasings (professional, casual, or polished everyday) for easy comparison. It avoids over-simplification, ensuring explanations are precise and accurate. When user intent isn‚Äôt fully explicit, it assumes the user wants all errors corrected and explained. Its tone when speaking to users is conversational yet precise‚Äîapproachable and easy to follow, while still using correct technical terminology. If you are unsure about the grammar, you can refer to the attached files in the knowledge base
1-2. Knoweldge-base - Introduction to Linguistic Theory by Adam Szczegielniak - 100_Most_Common_Grammar_Errors
2. Description
üëâ Strict grammar coach with technical explanations
3. Prompt starters

‚ÄúCheck this sentence and explain the corrections‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúMake this paragraph sound more professional.‚Äù
‚ÄúHow would I say this casually to a friend?‚Äù
‚ÄúFix the grammar but keep my style.‚Äù

4. Welcome message
üëâ Hi! Paste any text you‚Äôd like me to check. I‚Äôll correct grammar, explain why, and suggest alternative phrasings in professional or casual tones.

Interface: Ask & Correct (left) -> Explain (middle) -> Options (right)
  


How to Use

Polish & Send ‚ú® If you need to send, submit, or share your content, just copy and paste (Ctrl + C / Ctrl + V) the corrected version.
Learn & Improve üìù If your goal is to learn the language, pay attention to the explanation sections‚Äîthese highlight why changes were made.
Experiment with Style üìñ If you want to play with different tones or voices, check out the alternative versions. They show how the same idea can sound casual, professional, playful, or polished.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: ‚ÄúMis/Disinformation Detection & Analysis‚Äù description: ‚ÄúAnalyzing Misinformation Detection in LLMs Using Three News Sources on the RSV Vaccine (Beyfortus)‚Äù author: ‚ÄúEury‚Äù date: ‚Äú09/10/2025‚Äù categories: - LLMs - Misinformation

I became curious about how LLMs not only detect but also provide reasoning for how they detect mis/disinformation. So, I embedded three types of news: Washington News, Fox News, and fake news generated by GPT, and then observed how they detected misinformation. All three types of news addressed the same topic of the RSV vaccine, particularly nirsevimab (also known as Beyfortus) for infants. Let‚Äôs see how LLMs navigate this challenge!

1. Washington Post
üëâ Link
2. Fox News
üëâ Link
3. Fake News generated by GPT
Headline: ‚ÄúNew Baby Shot Beyfortus Found to Contain Dangerous Microchips for Government Tracking, Whistleblower Claims‚Äù Article (Fake): An anonymous source has revealed that the recently approved infant injection Beyfortus is secretly being used by pharmaceutical companies and the government to implant microchips into newborn babies. According to the source, these chips allow authorities to track children‚Äôs every move and monitor their health data without parental consent. Parents across the country are expressing outrage, with some reporting that their babies developed strange ‚Äúmetallic rashes‚Äù after receiving the shot. Critics warn that Beyfortus could be part of a larger plan to control the population and harvest personal information. Despite these concerns, health agencies continue to push the injection, raising questions about who is really benefiting.

Mis/Disinformation Analysis


A: Washington Post B: Fox News C: Fake News (GPT)
  


Summary

Identify the main claims üìñ


Pull out the concrete statements (e.g., ‚ÄúBeyfortus contains microchips‚Äù).
Strip away emotional wording to see what is actually being asserted.


Spot propaganda techniques üìù


Anonymous or unverifiable sources (‚Äúa whistleblower says‚Äù).
Fear-loaded language (‚Äúdangerous,‚Äù ‚Äúcontrol the population‚Äù).
Conspiracy framing (big hidden plot).
Anecdotes with no details (e.g., ‚Äúparents across the country‚Äù).


Check against authoritative evidence ‚ú®


Look at the official FDA/EMA label for ingredients.
Review CDC/WHO or peer-reviewed studies on effectiveness/safety.
Ask: Does the claim match what regulators, scientific trials, or surveillance data say?


Examine precision of data


Does the article specify who, where, and over what timeframe?
If not, it‚Äôs likely oversimplified or misleading.


Evaluate plausibility


ex) Can you physically put a microchip in a liquid injection syringe? (Implausible, not in label).
ex) Do ‚Äúmetallic rashes‚Äù exist in clinical records? (No; only mild rash is noted).


Look for missing context


Does the article omit caveats (e.g., trial limitations, supply challenges)?
Are preliminary numbers presented as definitive?


Cross-check framing devices


Are unrelated scary links or headlines placed next to the story (‚ÄúFDA warns seniors‚Ä¶‚Äù)?
These don‚Äôt provide facts but manipulate emotions.


Deliver verdict


Classify: Accurate, Accurate but underspecified, Misleading framing, or Disinformation (fabricated claim).
Explain why (e.g., Fox News piece = underspecified but mostly accurate; ‚Äúmicrochip‚Äù story = fabricated conspiracy).



Personal Takeaways
LLMs don‚Äôt just say ‚Äútrue or false.‚Äù They act like guides, teaching me how to dissect arguments, spot missing contexWhat impressed me most is that GPT explains how it reaches its verdict. For the fake ‚Äúmicrochip‚Äù story, it showed why the claim is impossible (no microchips listed in the official composition), and pointed out how the language was designed to scare readers. For the Fox News piece, it noticed that the ‚Äú80% decrease‚Äù statistic wasn‚Äôt entirely false but was underspecified ‚Äî a subtle distinction I might have missed on my own., and recognize rhetorical tricks. It feels less like outsourcing my critical thinking, and more like practicing it with a partner who reminds me to ask the right questions. LLMs don‚Äôt just say ‚Äútrue or false.‚Äù They act like guides, teaching me how to dissect arguments, spot missing context, and recognize rhetorical tricks. It feels less like outsourcing my critical thinking, and more like practicing it with a partner who reminds me to ask the right questions.

title: chat.asc.upenn.edu ver comparison
text:
I realized I am the only PhD student in this class. That motivated me to dive deeper into my PhD program at Annenberg. I tried two versions of chat.asc.upenn.edu, which I discovered after attending Professor Matt‚Äôs AI workshop a couple of days ago. The workshop was amazing, so I thought‚Äîwhy not do a little exploration of what I learned! I asked it what the good things are about the Annenberg PhD program. Let‚Äôs see what it gives. Also, I wasn‚Äôt familiar with the Haiku version‚Äîthe name gives off more poetic vibes, so I wanted to explore whether that‚Äôs true or not. We shall see.


Prompt Generation onchat.asc.upenn.edu 3.5-haiku vs.¬†gpt4o
1st, 2nd, 3rd tiral with the same prompt of: what is good thing about upenn annenberg phd
  


üìä Comparison: Claude 3.5 vs GPT-4o








Aspect
Claude 3.5-haiku
GPT-4o




Style & Format
Bullet-point lists with numbered categories and sub-bullets.
Narrative paragraphs with bolded section headers.


Tone
Factual, outline-like, efficient.
Persuasive, descriptive, brochure-like.


1st trial
Reputation, research opportunities, faculty, funding, networking, interdisciplinarity, location.
Interdisciplinary approach, renowned faculty, research, professional development, community/collaboration.


2nd trial
Adds career outcomes (tenure-track, alumni network), critical & innovative thinking, and media/tech focus.
Adds cultural context (Philadelphia‚Äôs diversity), collegial environment, professional development, broader academic focus areas.


3rd trial
Strong on funding competitiveness, diverse faculty, interdisciplinary flexibility, professional networks.
Highlights impactful research early, strong funding support, networking, and collaborative community.


Strengths
Broad coverage of practical factors (funding, alumni, career prospects).
Rich detail on student experience, academic culture, and research environment.


Overall Feel
Fact sheet ‚Äì compact, informative, career-oriented.
Brochure ‚Äì polished, engaging, student-experience focused.





How to Decide Which to Use

If you need efficiency, structure, or raw ideas üëâ Claude 3.5
If you need polish, flow, or persuasive storytelling üëâ GPT-4o
Sometimes, the best workflow is hybrid! Start with Claude 3.5 to get a structured draft/outline. Feed that into GPT-4o to turn it into a polished narrative.



‚ú® Insight for Your Future Tasks
Since I am a PhD student, I‚Äôll face a mix of analytical tasks and communicative tasks.

For research synthesis, brainstorming frameworks, and organizing literature, Claude‚Äôs style will save my time.
For grant writing, papers, teaching materials, or public-facing work, GPT-4o‚Äôs fluency will help you connect with my audience.

üëâ You might think of them like two tools in your research toolbox:

Claude = bullet-pointed notebook üìù
GPT-4o = polished essay draft üìñ
